Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Massachusetts law provides a statutory right to quiet enjoyment for residential tenants, which landlords are obligated to ensure under Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, § 14.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s actions and omissions also violate the protections afforded tenants under common law and Massachusetts jurisprudence, including cases such as Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (affirming tenants' entitlement to quiet enjoyment under Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, § 14), and Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (establishing landlord liability for breaches of quiet enjoyment arising from third-party actions that the landlord could control).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Doe for the point that tenants are entitled to quiet enjoyment under Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, § 14. This opinion squarely addresses that statute, explains the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and holds that the tenants stated a viable § 14 claim based on serious interference with their tenancy caused by drug activity and the landlord’s omissions. The court reverses summary judgment on the quiet enjoyment claim and confirms that tenants may obtain damages and injunctive relief under § 14, so the case is accurately cited for that principle.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference. … We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Defendant’s actions and omissions also violate the protections afforded tenants under common law and Massachusetts jurisprudence, including cases such as Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (affirming tenants' entitlement to quiet enjoyment under Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, § 14), and Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (establishing landlord liability for breaches of quiet enjoyment arising from third-party actions that the landlord could control).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord can be liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, amounting to constructive eviction, where the disturbance arises from another tenant’s operations that the landlord had the right and ability to control. The court emphasizes that the landlords created the situation by leasing to the lounge, had contractual control over the lounge’s noise, and therefore could be held responsible for that third party’s conduct. This aligns with the proposition that Blackett establishes landlord liability for quiet enjoyment breaches caused by third-party actions the landlord can control.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge… we decline to perpetuate that distinction where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (holding landlords accountable for ongoing tenant disturbances);
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case holds a landlord liable where repeated, preventable flooding—caused or allowed to continue by the landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions—interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment and caused emotional distress. In addressing Gem’s argument that third-party tenant conduct caused the flooding, the court explicitly states that this was a preventable situation that the landlord had a duty to prevent and affirms liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14. While the “disturbances” here are environmental (flooding/sewage) rather than, for example, noisy neighbors, the opinion does hold landlords accountable for ongoing, preventable interferences with a tenant’s occupancy.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “As its third objection to Solomon’s recovery on her count for interference with quiet enjoyment, Gem asserts that it was wrongly held responsible for the actions of third parties beyond its control… Gem argues that it was unable to control the source of the flooding. … This contention echoes Gem’s objections to the verdict for reckless infliction of emotional distress, and we reject it for the same reasons. The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. … Therefore, Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Bosse v. Litton Unit Construction Co., 2.raw_text: Bosse v. Litton Unit Construction Co., 288 Mass. 174 (1934)
Bosse v. Litton Unit Construction Co., 2.proposition: Bosse v. Litton Unit Construction Co., 288 Mass. 174 (1934) (discussing tenant remedies for interference with quiet enjoyment);
Bosse v. Litton Unit Construction Co., 2.case_name: McDonald v. Employers' Liability Assurance Corp.
Bosse v. Litton Unit Construction Co., 2.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an employee’s tort claim against a workers’ compensation insurer for negligent medical treatment and whether his prior election of workers’ compensation benefits bars the action. It does not involve landlord-tenant relations, quiet enjoyment, or tenant remedies for interference with quiet enjoyment. Therefore, citing this case for tenant remedies related to quiet enjoyment is inaccurate and unsupported by the text or holding.
Bosse v. Litton Unit Construction Co., 2.relevant_excerpt: G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 152, § 15, provides in part that where “under circumstances creating a legal liability in some person other than the insured to pay damages in respect thereof, the employee may at his option proceed either at law against that person to recover damages or against the insurer for compensation under this chapter, but not against both.” ... The exercise of his option in favor of proceeding for compensation precluded him from maintaining an action at law for damages...

Armstrong v. Rondoni, 67 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Armstrong v. Rondoni, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 377 (2006)
Armstrong v. Rondoni, 67 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Armstrong v. Rondoni, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 377 (2006) (addressing consequences for violations of tenant rights to habitable living conditions);
Armstrong v. Rondoni, 67 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Choate v. Zoning Board of Appeals
Armstrong v. Rondoni, 67 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion is a zoning/land use and standing case involving variances for undersized lots and access-road safety; it does not concern landlord-tenant law, habitability standards, or remedies for violations of tenants’ rights to habitable living conditions. Nothing in the holding or reasoning addresses tenant rights, warranties of habitability, or consequences for substandard rental conditions, so citing it for that proposition would be inaccurate and out of context.
Armstrong v. Rondoni, 67 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "Only ‘person[s] aggrieved’ within the meaning of G. L. c. 40A, § 17, have standing to seek judicial review of a decision of a zoning board of appeals.... A person is ‘aggrieved’ by the board’s action if the person asserts ‘a plausible claim of a definite violation of a private right, a private property interest, or a private legal interest.’"

Chiancola v. Bauman, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 3.raw_text: Chiancola v. Bauman, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 397 (2002)
Chiancola v. Bauman, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 3.proposition: Chiancola v. Bauman, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 397 (2002) (examining damages recoverable for breaches of quiet enjoyment);
Chiancola v. Bauman, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 3.support_reasoning: The reproduced opinion text is not Chiancola v. Bauman but Dziamba v. Warner & Stackpole, a discrimination and employment case. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or damages for breach of quiet enjoyment. Accordingly, this opinion cannot be relied on as authority for examining damages recoverable for breaches of quiet enjoyment.
Chiancola v. Bauman, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 3.relevant_excerpt:
We affirm.

1. Judge’s comments and ruling on plaintiff’s submission under Superior Court Rule 9A(b)(5). We have the assistance of a careful, thoughtful, and detailed memorandum of decision from the Superior Court judge who considered the materials and arguments on the motion for summary judgment. She made comments and rulings concerning the plaintiff’s (as the party opposing summary judgment) statement pursuant to Superior Court Rule 9A(b)(5) (1998) that raise a threshold issue about the consequences of failure to comply with that rule.

Rosenblatt v. Foley, 252 Mass. 188 (1925.proposition: Rosenblatt v. Foley, 252 Mass. 188 (1925) (highlighting a landlord's obligations regarding tenant disturbances).
Rosenblatt v. Foley, 252 Mass. 188 (1925.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns when an action is deemed commenced for statute-of-limitations purposes against executors of an estate. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, tenant disturbances, or any obligations of a landlord regarding disturbances. Therefore, citing this case for a landlord’s obligations about tenant disturbances misrepresents its holding.
Rosenblatt v. Foley, 252 Mass. 188 (1925.relevant_excerpt: “An action is commenced when a writ issues out and is delivered to an officer with a bona fide intent to have it served upon the defendant. … The burden of proof was upon the plaintiff to establish by affirmative evidence that the action was commenced within the time required by the statute…”
